III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry
Description (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and suitable
and able to meet the needs of children and families served by the
agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Allegation #1 The caregiver asked for social security cards and
birth certificates last year but still does not have all of them and
needs to enroll one of the kids in school for the fall.
Allegation # 2 The case manager is provided with medical
appointment information but never provides this information to the
respondent mother so she can attend.
Allegation # 3 The agency has not provided a trauma
assessment for one of the youths as requested.
Allegation #4 The foster parent was not reimbursed for mileage.
Allegation #5 The agency provides unsigned/incomplete
paperwork to the foster parent, requests a signature, and never
provides a copy later.
Investigation Several concerns were reported which were investigated
under the staff ability to provide for the needs of youths and
families served by the agency. Interviews were conducted as
follows for those concerns:
Caregiver was interviewed by phone on 6/19/2025.
Program Manager was interviewed via video conferencing on
7/3/2025.
Foster Care Worker 2 was interviewed by phone on 7/3/2025.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 was interviewed by phone on
7/9/2025.
Foster Care Supervisor 2 was interviewed by phone on 7/9/2025
Allegation #1 The caregiver asked for social security cards and
birth certificates last year but still does not have all of them and
needs to enroll one of the kids in school for the fall.
INTERVIEWS
Caregiver reported she is a fictive kin caregiver to Youth A, Youth
B, and Youth C. She stated she has had two different workers and
two different supervisors assigned to the case who she has
reached out to about her concerns. She reported agency staff (did
not specify who) informed her of agency policy that caregivers are
to be provided with a youth’s social security card and birth
certificate within 30 days of placement. She stated she received
2

Youth B’s social security card and birth certificate last week,
despite his having been in her care since July of 2024. Caregiver
reported she knows Youth B’s family and did not believe Youth B
had a social security card number, but the agency staff insisted he
did, yet they did not provide the number until recently. She stated
there was an issue with establishing paternity for Youth B, but that
was resolved several months ago, and she still does not have an
amended birth certificate.
Program Manager stated there were performance concerns with
Foster Care Worker 1 who ended up leaving while under a
corrective action plan, after which Foster Care Worker 2 was
assigned. Foster Care Worker 2 was initially supervised by Foster
Care Supervisor 1, but there were issues with the training and
supervision being provided to Foster Care Worker 2 as well as
Foster Care Worker 2’s performance, so she was recently
reassigned to Foster Care Supervisor 2, a more experienced
supervisor. Program Manager reported Foster Care Worker 2 has
resigned from the agency and her last day was the day of this
interview. Program Manager stated she is pretty familiar with this
case. She stated, when Youth B came into care, he did not have a
social security number, so the agency staff were working with
MDHHS POS Monitor to apply for one. Program Manager was not
sure of the specific timeframe, but stated it took a while to obtain
the social security number. Program Manager reported Caregiver
was provided with the social security number after it was assigned
to Youth B. As far as the birth certificate is concerned, Program
Manager stated Caregiver is confused. Parent A was married to
Parent B at the time of Youth B’s birth; however, Parent C has
recently established biological paternity through DNA testing.
Currently, Parent B is still the legal father as Parent C has not
established legal paternity, so there is no amendment to Youth B’s
birth certificate.
Foster Care Worker 2 indicated today is her last day at the
agency in part due to the lack of training, supervision, and support
she received which led to her feeling as if she was an ineffective
worker. Foster Care Worker 2 stated she was not the initial
worker assigned to the case but was assigned 12/20/2024. She
stated Caregiver told her she didn’t have a social security number
for Youth B in February of 2025, which she needed to file her
taxes. Foster Care Worker 2 reached out to MDHHS POS Monitor
who assisted in applying for the number. Foster Care Worker 2
was informed by MDHHS POS Monitor that Youth B was assigned
a social security number on 6/11/2025 after which the number was
provided to Caregiver. Foster Care Worker 2 stated she did not
3

know much about Youth B’s birth certificate being provided to
Caregiver as she already had one when Foster Care Worker 2
was assigned the case. Foster Care Worker 2 stated Parent C
established paternity through DNA testing, but Parent B is still
Youth B’s legal father.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 stated she supervised the case from
December of 2024 until May of 2025 during which time Foster
Care Worker 2 was assigned to the case. She stated that it was
discovered during an audit there was no social security number for
Youth B in MiSACWIS, so Foster Care Supervisor 1 reached out
to MDHHS POS Monitor on 2/18/2025 to ask for the social
security number to be entered. A response was received on
2/19/2025 indicating they did not have a number for Youth B, so
the agency staff needed to ask his parents for the number.
Caregiver informed Foster Care Worker 2 that Youth B was never
assigned a social security number, which Foster Care Worker 2
reported to MDHHS POS Monitor on 2/24/2025. On 4/1/2025,
MDHHS POS Monitor applied for Youth B’s social security
number; however, on 4/15/2025 MDHHS POS Monitor reached
out stating Foster Care Worker 2 needed to fill out the social
security application, which she did on 4/16/2025. There was no
response as of 5/12/2025, so Foster Care Worker 2 reached out
to MDDHS POS Monitor stating Caregiver could not complete her
taxes without the number. MDHHS POS Monitor responded on
6/11/2025 with Youth B’s social security number which was
provided to Caregiver. Foster Care Supervisor 1 stated the
agency does not have a policy about providing foster parents or
caregivers with a youth’s social security number or birth certificate
adding these documents are typically not given unless they are
requested. She stated the agency staff provide youths’ birth
certificates directly to schools for their enrollment, so Caregiver
does not need one for that purpose.
Foster Care Supervisor 2 stated she was assigned to supervise
Foster Care Worker 2 on June 2, 2025, due to Foster Care
Worker 2 not having received proper training by her previous
supervisor and Foster Care Supervisor 2 being more experienced.
She stated she was aware of Youth B never having been
assigned a social security number at birth and there being a lot of
hoops to jump through to get one. She stated there has been no
court hearing since she has taken over supervision of the case
and there has been no legal change to Youth B’s paternity or birth
certificate.
4

Documents Reviewed
7/30/2025 Email from Chief Administrator stating the agency does
not have any policies regarding providing birth certificates or
social security numbers to caregivers.
The following email chain was forwarded by Foster Care
Worker 2:
• 2/19/25 – Foster Care Supervisor 1 to MDHHS POS
Monitor requesting Youth B’s social security number be
uploaded to his case record.
• 2/19/2025 - MDHHS POS Monitor to Foster Care
Supervisor 2 indicating there is no social security number in
the record and requesting Foster Care Supervisor 1 ask
Youth A’s parents for the number and/or card.
• 2/24/2025 – Foster Care Supervisor 1 to MDHHS POS
Monitor stating the parents told her Youth A never had a
social security number and asking for the next steps to
obtain this.
• 4/15/2025 – MDHHS POS Monitor to Foster Care
Supervisor 2 stating a request was sent to the social
security administration who confirmed a number was never
assigned to Youth B. She requested Foster Care
Supervisor 1 fill out an application and sent it back to
MDHHS POS Monitor who would then forward to the social
security administration.
• 4/16/2025 – Foster Care Worker 2 to MDHHS POS Monitor
with the completed application attached.
• 4/18/2025 – MDHHS POS Monitor to Foster Care Worker 2
confirming receipt of the application.
• 5/12/2025 - Foster Care Supervisor 2 to MDHHS POS
Monitor requesting an update.
• 5/16/2025 - MDHHS POS Monitor to Foster Care
Supervisor 2 indicating a second request was sent to the
social security administration as there has been no update.
• 6/11/2025 - MDHHS POS Monitor to Foster Care
Supervisor 2 with Youth B’s social security number.
Allegation # 2 The case manager is provided with medical
appointment information but never provides this information to the
respondent mother so she can attend.
5

INTERVIEWS
Caregiver reported she tells her assigned Foster Care Worker 2
whenever she schedules a medical appointment for any of the
youths so Foster Care Worker 2 can inform the parents. She
stated the parents don’t attend the appointments because the
worker never tells them about the appointments. She stated she
knows this because Parent A tells her.
Program Manager was interviewed via video conferencing on
7/3/2025. She stated she does not know if the court has ordered
the parents to attend medical appointments or if they are
attending.
Foster Care Worker 2 was interviewed by phone on 7/3/2025.
She reported that the agency Health Liaison Officer schedules the
youths’ medical appointments, but Caregiver takes the youths to
her medical provider on different dates. Foster Care Worker 2
stated Caregiver informs Parent C, with whom she has been in a
relationship, of the appointments; however, she does not inform
Foster Care Worker 2 of the appointments or where they are
taking place so Foster Care Worker 2 can inform Parent A. Foster
Care Worker 2 stated there is not a court order regarding the
parents’ attendance as medical appointments.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 was interviewed by phone on
7/9/2025. She states she believed Parent A was made aware of
all the youths’ medical appointments.
Foster Care Supervisor 2 was interviewed by phone on
7/9/2025. She reported Caregiver and Parent C were in a
relationship at the onset of the case and might still be in a
relationship. She stated Caregiver will change medical and other
appointments at the last minute and inform Parent C, but not
Foster Care Worker 2 or Parent A.
Documents Reviewed
Court orders from hearings that were held on 12/4/2024,
2/26/2025, and 5/21/2025, none of which included an order for the
parents to attend medical appointments.
Family Team Meeting/Team Decision Making documentation
within each youth’s case record.
• 1/10/2025 documenting it was approved for Caregiver to
pick up parents to attend medical appointments.
6

Well-Child appointments documented to have occurred after
placement with Caregiver:
• Youth A - None
• Youth B – 5/13/2025 medical appointment was to be
scheduled at Spectrum Health; however, paperwork from
the appointment documents Caregiver’s mother brought
Youth B to an appointment at Corwell Health.
• Youth C – 2/21/2025 HLO documented a well child was
scheduled for 1/21/2025 and was rescheduled to
2/27/2025. The 2/27/2025 appointment was unkept as it
was scheduled with a specific provider at Spectrum Health
and Caregiver brought Youth C to a different provider at
Corwell Health on 2/21/2025. Parent A’s visit was cancelled
2/27/2025 due to her having COVID; therefore, she would
have been unable to attend the appointment.
Allegation # 3 The agency has not provided a trauma
assessment for one of the youths as requested.
INTERVIEWS
Caregiver reported that Youth A & Youth B need trauma
assessments. She stated their respective therapists
recommended trauma assessments several months ago, yet
those assessments have not been scheduled. Caregiver stated
her worker initially stated they could not be done without a letter
from the therapist, which was provided to her. The worker then
reported an issue scheduling the assessments due to the case
being in Kent County and the Caregiver living in Montcalm
County. Most recently, Foster Care Worker 2 has told her she was
trying to find a place to do the assessments.
Program Manager stated she did know about the trauma
assessments needed for this case.
Foster Care Worker 2 reported Youth B’s mental health provider
in Montcalm County recommended a trauma assessment for
Youth B, which Foster Care Worker 2 communicated to Clinical
Liaison. On 5/8/2025, Clinical Liaison responded to Foster Care
Worker 2 stating she needed to obtain the recommendation in
writing, which Foster Care Worker 2 did and returned to Clinical
Liaison. Foster Care Worker 2 received a response that the form
she submitted was outdated, so she needed to fill out a new one.
After returning that form, she received an email from Clinical
Liaison stating she needed to submit quarterly reports from the
assigned enhanced foster care worker. Once those were
7

submitted, Clinical Liaison responded to Enhanced Foster Care
Worker that there was not enough information in those reports.
Foster Care Worker 2 stated she hasn’t heard anything since.
Foster Care Worker 2 stated Youth A had a trauma assessment 1-
2 years ago. Foster Care Worker 2 expressed her thoughts that
Youth A could benefit from a new trauma assessment as her
father is now out of jail and she has experienced a placement
disruption; however, Youth A’s mental health provider has not
recommended a new trauma assessment.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 reported the agency staff have been
trying to get trauma assessments for Youth B and other youths,
but MDHHS staff keep saying they are ineligible, which had been
frustrating for staff and families. She reported working with West
Michigan Partnership for Children (WMPC) staff to secure a
trauma assessment for Youth B since December of 2024. She
stated she is still copied on all the communication regarding the
trauma assessments despite no longer being the assigned
supervisor and she received an email earlier in the day from
Clinical Liaison indicating there were needed revisions to the
request for Youth B’s trauma assessment.
Foster Care Supervisor 2 reported she is not aware of any
concerns with securing trauma assessments for these youths. It
was recommended she reach out to Foster Care Supervisor 1 to
obtain the email chains regarding the trauma assessments so she
can follow-up as she indicated she will be assigned the case after
Foster Care Worker 2 leaves until a new worker is assigned.
Documents Reviewed
3/5/2025 Letter from Youth B’s mental health provider
recommending Youth B receive a trauma assessment.
The following email chain was forwarded by Foster Care
Worker 2:
• 3/21/2025 Foster Care Worker 2 to Foster Care Supervisor
2 with a letter from Youth B’s mental health provider
recommending a trauma assessment attached.
• 5/8/2025 Foster Care Worker 2 to Clinical Liaison with
completed referral form for Youth B’s trauma assessment
• 5/20/2025 Foster Care Supervisor 2 to Clinical Liaison with
Youth B’s Initial Service Plan, Court petition and preliminary
hearing orders, 8/2/2024 trauma screen and most recent
service plan
8

• 6/2/2025 from MDHHS Supervisor to Clinical Liaison and
Foster Care Worker 2 indicating corrections needed on the
submitted referral form as well as the need for Enhanced
Foster Care and mental health provider reports.
Social Work Contacts within Youth A’s case record:
• No additional contacts regarding progress toward the
request for a trauma assessment were located.
Allegation #4 The foster parent was not reimbursed for mileage.
INTERVIEWS
Caregiver reported she has turned in over $1000 worth of
mileage reimbursement request forms in the 11 months she has
been providing care. She stated Foster Care Worker 1 did not do
anything with the forms. When Foster Care Worker 2 was
assigned to the case in December 2024, Caregiver asked about
the mileage forms. Foster Care Worker 2 stated she located the
forms on Foster Care Worker 1’s desk and would submit them.
When Caregiver did not hear any updates, she again submitted all
her forms to Foster Care Worker 2. Caregiver recently asked
about the reimbursement and was told by Foster Care Worker 2
there was a meeting scheduled to discuss her mileage.
Program Manager indicated she was not aware of Caregiver not
having been reimbursed for her mileage. She stated she does not
know of any meeting scheduled to discuss mileage but guessed
Foster Care 2 might have been referencing a meeting with her
supervisor to learn how to submit mileage for reimbursement.
Foster Care Worker 2 stated the mileage reimbursement issue
for Caregiver was “truly frustrating.” She stated Caregiver asked
her about mileage reimbursement after which Foster Care Worker
2 found unprocessed mileage forms on Foster Care Worker 1’s
desk. Caregiver gave Foster Care Worker 2 all her mileage forms,
including copies of the forms she previously submitted, in March
of 2025 after which Foster Care Worker 2 set up multiple meetings
with her supervisor to learn how to submit the mileage for
reimbursement. Foster Care Worker 2 stated the meetings kept
getting cancelled, so she never learned how to submit the mileage
for reimbursement.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 stated she has been telling Foster
Care Worker 2 to submit Caregiver’s mileage for reimbursement
since it was received from Caregiver. She stated she showed
9

Foster Care Worker 2 how to submit mileage for reimbursement,
but she did not remember when and there was no documentation
of this occurring. When asked if there was any training or meeting
regarding mileage cancelled by Foster Care Supervisor 1, she
stated she didn’t remember that happening and did not see
anything on her calendar when searching.
Foster Care Supervisor 2 stated she does not know the rationale
as to why the mileage was never submitted for reimbursement,
other than the possibility of worker turnover. She stated she will
reach out to Caregiver for copies of her mileage forms. She was
advised Foster Care Worker 2 has copies.
Documents Reviewed
Agency Foster Care- Foster Parent Mileage Process Map
documenting the process for foster care workers to request
mileage reimbursement. No timeframes were attached to any of
the steps.
Allegation # 5 The agency provides unsigned/incomplete
paperwork to the foster parent, requests a signature, and never
provides a copy later.
INTERVIEWS
Caregiver reported when Youth A was placed in her home a few
months ago she was asked to sign what she believes were
temporary placement documents that were partially blank. Foster
Care Worker 2 stated she would give Caregiver a copy but still
has not done so.
Program Manager reported having spoken to Caregiver a few
times, but she never mentioned anything about paperwork not
being filled out correctly or provided.
Foster Care Worker 2 stated when Youth A was placed in
Caregiver’s home, Foster Care Supervisor 1 gave her a
replacement packet to give to Caregiver since it was Foster Care
Worker 2’s first time facilitating a replacement. Foster Care
Worker 2 gave the paperwork to Caregiver and, the following day,
Caregiver called her to state the paperwork wasn’t filled out
completely. Foster Care Worker does not know what specifically
was missing; however, she stated there is a Teams chat in which
Enhanced Foster Care Worker discussed the paperwork that was
missing information. Foster Care Worker 2 stated she would find
the chat and send screenshots.
10

Foster Care Supervisor 1 was interviewed by phone on
7/9/2025. She stated she went over the replacement checklist and
paperwork with Foster Care Worker 2 but didn’t verify all the
paperwork was complete prior to Foster Care Worker 2 providing
it to Caregiver. When asked if she filled out the paperwork or if
Foster Care Worker 2 did, Foster Care Supervisor 1 stated she
didn’t remember.
Documents Reviewed
Screenshots of a Teams chat emailed by Foster Care Worker
2:
• 3/25/2025
o Enhanced Foster Care Worker asking for help
locating Youth A’s medical passport or Michigan
Beneficiary ID number for Caregiver prior to Youth
A’s medical appointment.
o Foster Care Supervisor 1 stating the medical
consent-to-treat form was filled out by Foster Care
Supervisor 2 and would have been provided by
Foster Care Worker 2 to Caregiver in person.
o Enhanced Foster Care Worker stating she found the
form with Youth A’s number on it from a previous
placement, but the copy Caregiver has does not
have the number. Enhanced Foster Care Worker
gave the number to Caregiver.
• 3/26/2025
o Enhanced Foster Care Worker attached a photo of
Caregiver’s medical consent to treat card which is
missing Youth A’s Medical Beneficiary ID.
o Foster Care Supervisor 1 responded “that’s my bad.”
Replacement paperwork:
• Replacement checklist and replacement outline signed
by Caregiver. The only sections not filled in are sections
in which information isn’t required.
• Consent to Routine Non-Surgical Medical Care card
which includes Youth A’s recipient ID.
Analysis ANALYSIS:
The agency is found in compliance as agency staff did not
demonstrate an inability to meet the needs of the youths and
families served by the agency.
11

Allegation #1 - When agency staff became aware of Caregiver’s
need for a social security number, they reached out to MDHHS
staff. The number was not assigned to the youth by the social
security administration and provided to the agency staff for four
months.
Allegation # 2 – The two well-child appointments that were
documented to have occurred were scheduled with the youths’
medical providers; however, Caregiver brought the youths to well-
child appointments at a different provider without notifying the
agency.
Allegation #3 – A trauma assessment was recommended by
Youth A’s mental health provider. There is no documentation
related to a request for a trauma assessment until 2 months after
that recommendation was made so it is unknown what was done
during that time; however, once documentation of a referral for a
trauma assessment began, it is documented the agency staff have
been responding to all requests for information related to obtaining
the trauma assessment for Youth B, timely.
Allegation #4 – Agency policy does not dictate a timeframe in
which caregivers (in this case, unlicensed fictive kin) are to be
reimbursed for mileage.
Allegation #5 -While it was not clear what incomplete paperwork
Caregiver signed and did not receive copies of when Youth A was
placed in her home, replacement paperwork was reviewed and
found to contain all required information at the time of placement.
There was discussion of Caregiver not being provided the youth’s
Medicaid number on the consent to treat card; however, this was
not something signed by Caregiver, Additionally, the number was
provided to Caregiver when requested.
CONSULTATION:
• Consider adding review of each youth’s record for a social
security number at intake to ensure a number has been
assigned to the youth.
• Ensure all actions related to obtaining a trauma
assessment for a youth are documented in case contacts.
Supervisor 2 should follow up with Supervisor 1 to obtain
her recent contacts regarding the trauma assessment so
she can continue to follow-up and secure the service.
• Consider adding a timeframe to policies/procedures related
to timeframes in which workers must process mileage
reimbursement requests to ensure caregivers are
12

reimbursed in a reasonable amount of time. In this case,
Foster Care Supervisor 2 should follow-up with Caregiver
to ensure immediate processing of her past-due mileage.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person
Section contact.
Description • (1) An agency shall develop a plan of visitation and family
time for each child in foster care consistent with the child's
service plans, as required by R 400.12419 and R
400.12420 to ensure the safety and well-being of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency would not reschedule parenting time for 3 foster youth
when it was needed due to surgery of one of the youths. The
agency could not provide the policy that adheres to this practice
when it was requested.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Caregiver reported one of the youths had surgery which took
place during scheduled parenting time. The parents went to the
surgery after which Foster Care Worker 2 cancelled the parenting
time for that day. When Caregiver asked when the parenting time
took place, Foster Care Worker 2 told her the surgery would be
considered parenting time. No explanation was provided as to why
parenting time was cancelled for the other two youths who were
not present during the surgery.
Caregiver stated, in the beginning of the case, a lot of parenting
times were cancelled due to lice or illnesses, which Caregiver
understood; however, there were multiple times the agency staff
cancelled parenting times because they did not have anyone to
supervise the visit or for other unknown reasons. Caregiver stated
the agency staff never made up any of those parenting times. She
stated parenting time for Parent A was recently changed from
supervised to unsupervised. A Team Decision Making (TDM)
meeting was held during which it was established Parent A’s
Sunday visits were flexible and that she needed to text both
Foster Care Worker 2 and Caregiver by 5:00pm on Wednesdays
to let them know she will be attending her Sunday visit and where
the visit is to take place. She stated the first two visits following the
TDM went fine, and Parent A communicated as agreed upon.
Parent A did not show up for the 3rd visit and did not text Caregiver
on Wednesday for the 4th visit. Caregiver reached out to Foster
Care Worker 2 the following Thursday and Caregiver was told
Parent A had confirmed the visit with Foster Care Worker 2 so it
13

would be taking place. Caregiver asked Foster Care Worker 2 for
a screenshot of this communication as she had not received
anything after which Caregiver received an email from Foster
Care Supervisor 2 stating Parent A was following what was
established during the TDM. Foster Care Worker 2 was on
vacation the following week and Caregiver did not receive a text
from Parent A on Wednesday, so she did reach out to the agency
and did not bring the youths anywhere for a visit with Parent A.
Program Manager stated she is aware of the visit concerns
related to Youth B’s surgery. She stated Visitation Specialist
misunderstood her supervisor, Foster Care Supervisor 2,
regarding the surgery and visitation. Program Manager stated
Foster Care Supervisor 2 would have more information about that
incident. Program Manager stated she is not aware of any visits
being cancelled and not made up and does not know if Parent A is
required to text Caregiver before visits.
Foster Care Worker 2 reported having been on paid time-off
when Youth B’s surgery occurred, but when she returned, she
was told by Visitation Specialist it is agency policy that if both
parents are present at a youth’s medical appointment, it counts as
parenting time, so there would be no additional visit offered.
Foster Care Worker 2 stated this did not make sense to her
because it was surgery, so they weren’t visiting with Youth B, and
Youth A and Youth C were not there. Foster Care Worker 2 stated
Foster Care Supervisor 2 was “stern” on not making up the visit.
Foster Care Worker 2 stated she wasn’t aware of the agency
cancelling visits due to not having anyone to supervise. She
stated there was a time when she first was assigned to the case
that Caregiver wanted to supervise visits which she did for a while.
In April of 2025, a visit was cancelled because Caregiver said the
agency was “using her.” That visit was rescheduled and
supervised by a different relative.
Foster Care Worker 2 reported the current protocol for visits is as
described by Caregiver. She stated Parent A reached out to
Foster Care Worker 2 directly requesting to change the day of one
of her visits. When Foster Care Worker 2 told her of the change,
Caregiver wanted Foster Care Worker 2 to give her a screenshot
of that request. Foster Care Worker 2 stated Caregiver “flipped
out” on her after which Foster Care Supervisor 2 told Caregiver
her behavior was inappropriate.
14

Foster Care Supervisor 1 reported she was not aware the visit
was cancelled because of Youth B’s surgery. She stated it doesn’t
make sense to her why that visit wouldn’t have been rescheduled
or made up. She stated she was never contacted about any
concerns with that visit.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 reported, at one point, there was a lot of
contention about who was supervising visits for this case. During a
Family Team Meeting (FTM) Caregiver asked to supervise visits.
She was told it would be fine for her to supervise, which she did
for a while. At one point, when Caregiver was told of a scheduled
visit, she became upset and stated the agency was using her, so
that visit was cancelled. That visit was rescheduled and occurred
with a different person supervising. Foster Care Supervisor 1 was
not aware of any other visits being cancelled.
Foster Care Supervisor 2 stated she supervises Visitation
Specialist who was responsible for the visits during the week of

Analysis A violation is being established as a youth’s surgery was used as
parenting time for one of two weekly visits despite only one of the
three youths being present. Social Work Contacts indicated
additional time would be offered at Youth B’s birthday party;
however, the agency cancelled a visit the week of the birthday
party. Therefore, only one visit occurred during the week of the
surgery as well as the following week, which does not align with
the visitation plan.
CONSULTATION:
• When discussing visitation plans during FTM/TDMs, ensure
the visitation plan is specific. If the 2 hours required by the
visitation plan are to occur through two 1-hour visits,
document that within the FTM/TDM documentation.
• When standards are implemented specifying how/when
parents are to communicate their attendance at parenting
time, put these standards in writing and provide to all
applicable parties.
